content.webTitle: Neil Woodford refuses to waive fees despite pressure from MPs and FCA

fields.headline: Neil Woodford refuses to waive fees despite pressure from MPs and FCA
fields.bodyText: Neil Woodford has refused to waive his £100,000-a-day investment management fee for his flagship fund despite demands from MPs and the UK financial regulator to scrap the charges after he prevented investors from withdrawing £3.7bn of their money. Woodford, who last year paid himself and his business partner £36.5m, said he would continue to collect the fees despite the intervention of Andrew Bailey, the chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), and Nicky Morgan MP, the chair of the Treasury select committee. Bailey said Woodford, who was once the City’s best-known stock-picker, “should should consider very seriously … his position”. Morgan said: “Others have suspended taking fees and I think Woodford should too, for the sake that I think that it’s something like £100,000 a day, potentially, in fees. “I mean, that is a huge amount of money and, as I say, there are investors who have put often, sometimes, their life savings or certainly money needed for important investments [in the fund]. And they’re watching that value drop.” A spokesman for Woodford Investment Management, which once held more than £10bn but is now worth less than £4bn after large investment losses and outflows of cash, said: “The company will continue to charge the fee as the fund remains actively managed and we focus on repositioning the portfolio.” James Anderson, the manager of Scottish Mortgage, a FTSE 100 investment trust, said it was “completely wrong” that Woodford was not waiving fees while dealings were suspended. He said fees are “one of the ethical issues that are under your control”. Woodford apologised to investors for a second time on Tuesday, telling them in a letter sent via brokers, that he was “deeply sorry” for the “anxiety that the suspension has caused you”. “I realise this will be concerning and frustrating to you and I am sorry for putting you in this situation,” he added. But Woodford defended his investment strategy, and said: “In my view, every position within the portfolio will continue to be united by one thing: under-valuation. Every asset in the portfolio has a fundamental value that significantly exceeds its share price. In some cases, in my judgement, the gap between value and price is as wide as I have ever seen in more than 30 years of public equity market investing.” The fund supermarket Hargreaves Lansdown, which sold and promoted Woodford products, has dropped its platform fees for clients affected by the suspension. Hargreaves said it was not fair to charge customers while they were barred from trading. Hargreaves is itself facing intense scrutiny from the FCA and MPs over its role in promoting Woodford’s fund in its influential “Wealth 50” ranking of favourite funds. Bailey said the FCA would “look again” at fund supermarkets including Hargreaves to ensure they were impartial. The FCA investigated best-buy lists in March but did not introduce new rules. Morgan has demanded that Bailey publish details of his contact with Woodford and that he confirm whether the City watchdog was planning a formal investigation into the events that led to the fund’s suspension. She said the debacle raised concerns that the FCA may have been asleep at the wheel as the fund manager tumbled into crisis. Bailey will face Morgan’s Treasury select committee for a public grilling on 25 June. Morgan demanded on Tuesday that Hargreaves explain its inclusion of Woodford’s fund in its Wealth 50 list. Hargreaves only removed Woodford Equity Income from the influential list when it froze withdrawals last week. She also asked the Hargreaves boss, Chris Hill, how much money the firm had made in fees from customers who had invested in Woodford’s fund. At the end of March, Hargreaves’s customers accounted for about £2bn of £10.6bn under Woodford’s management. Hill said: “We have received the letter of the chair of the Treasury select committee and will reply in due course.” The FCA also hit out at Woodford’s skirting City rules on holdings in privates companies by listing them on the Guernsey stock exchange. Doing this allowed him to stay with EU rules that limit the proportion of unlisted or illiquid investments to no more than 10% of assets. Bailey said that while the move was “allowable” and “within the rules” he disapproved of Woodford’s tactics. “I’ve said publicly I don’t think it is right. I think investors should be able to determine where their assets are held,” he said. But the Bank of England deputy governor Ben Broadbent came to the defence of the FCA during a parliamentary hearing on Tuesday, saying regulators shouldn’t be expected to safeguard investors to the point where they faced no risks. “You cannot have a system which collectively could reduce all risk to zero. I don’t think that’s possible and I don’t think that’s desirable. There is risk in these funds, there is risk in risky assets.”
